newsitem.title: UK: UK's Channel 5 may hurt Channel 4 and BBC2 - report.
newsitem.headline: UK's Channel 5 may hurt Channel 4 and BBC2 - report.

text.p: Britain's newest terrestrial television station Channel 5 is likely to win more of its audience from Channel 4 and BBC2 than from the mainstream BBC1 and ITV channels, a report released on Tuesday said.

"Channel 4 and BBC2 will lose disproportionately, and may permanently come off worse than ITV or BBC1," Zenith Media, the media-buying and planning arm of Cordiant Plc, said in its preview of Britain's spring television programme.

Channel 5, the first commercial terrestrial station to launch since Channel 4 began broadcasting in 1982, was launched on Sunday. Initial figures from the BARB monitoring service gave Channel 5 a 5.8 percent share of viewing in the 6 p.m. to 10:30 p.m. slot on Sunday, beating Channel 4's share of 4.7 percent.
Zenith, whose programme preview was written ahead of the Channel 5 debut, said it will be weeks or months befor e the new station's success or failure can be judged.
Channel 5 is owned by British media companies Pearson Plc and United News & Media Plc, as well as European broadcast group CLT-Ufa and U.S. private investment firm Warburg Pincus.
It aims for an audience somewhere between ITV's mass market and Channel 4's youth audience.
Zenith, meanwhile, sharply criticised ITV, saying it "...has slept through the alarm clocks of a revitalised BBC and a seriously commercial (Channel) 4."

ITV's responses to competition "...have been mechanical rather than inspired", Zenith said. It noted that ITV has been experiencing a falling share of the viewing audience, down to almost 34 percent in the first seven weeks of 1997 from 37 percent a year-earlier and 35 percent for all of 1996.
